questions.text: For the diagnosis of acute hepatitis B infection during the early phase (2-5 weeks’ post-exposure), which of the following markers is most reliable?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgM Anti-HBc

 

Option A:

 

IgM anti-HBc appears early in the course of a Hepatitis B infection and is a reliable marker for diagnosing acute hepatitis B, especially during the window period when HBsAg may have disappeared and anti-HBs is not yet detectable.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HBsAg - While HBsAg is an early marker of infection, it may not be as specific as IgM anti-HBc in the early phase.

 

Option C. Anti-HCV - This marker is specific for Hepatitis C virus infection, not Hepatitis B.

 

Option D. HBeAg - This indicates active viral replication but appears after HBsAg and is not as useful for early diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgM anti-HBc is the most reliable marker for the early diagnosis of acute hepatitis B infection, especially when interpreting serological tests within 2-5 weeks post-exposure.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p534-35, 2/e p557-558

choices.text: Hepatitis B vaccine and Hepatitis B immunoglobulins within 12 hours of delivery

questions.text: A newborn is delivered to a mother with active Hepatitis B infection. To prevent neonatal Hepatitis B infection, what prophylaxis should be administered?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B vaccine and Hepatitis B immunoglobulins within 12 hours of delivery

 

Option A:

 

The combination of Hepatitis B vaccine and Hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) given within 12 hours of birth is the recommended prophylaxis to prevent neonatal Hepatitis B infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Immunoglobulins only - While HBIG is crucial, it is most effective when given in combination with the vaccine.

 

Option C. Hepatitis B vaccine only - The vaccine is necessary but not sufficient on its own for immediate protection.

 

Option D. No prophylaxis is required - This is incorrect as the risk of transmission from mother to child is high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recommended prophylactic measures for newborns born to HBsAg-positive mothers to prevent vertical transmission of Hepatitis B- A single injection of 0.5 ml of HBIG given IM immediately after birth (passive immunization) followed by the full course of vaccine (active immunization) at a different anatomical site, the first dose being given within 12 hours of birth.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p535-36, 2/e p558-559, Ananthanarayan 9/e p548, 8/e p544

choices.text: Most patients have severe symptoms when infected for the first time.
Highly likely to cause chronic ongoing infection.
Transmitted by eating raw oysters.

questions.text: A public health campaign is raising awareness about Hepatitis C. Which statement accurately describes the nature of Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Highly likely to cause chronic ongoing infection.

 

Option B:

 

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is known for its propensity to cause chronic infections, with a 75-85 percentage of individuals developing a long-term illness following initial infection. Many individuals with acute HCV infection may not exhibit severe symptoms, and the virus can persist in a chronic state, leading to long-term liver damage, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Most patients have severe symptoms when infected for the first time - Incorrect, as most acute HCV infections are asymptomatic or only mildly symptomatic.

 

Option C. Transmitted by eating raw oysters - Incorrect, HCV is primarily transmitted through blood-to-blood contact, not through food.

 

Option D. It is a DNA virus - Incorrect, HCV is a RNA virus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCV infection is particularly notable for its high risk of becoming chronic; approximately 75-85% of those infected will develop chronic liver disease.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e, p560

choices.text: Acute Hepatitis B patient with high infectivity

questions.text: A hospital worker has tested positive for HBsAg and HBeAg. Further testing indicates the presence of IgG anti-HBc. Based on these serological findings, what is the most accurate description of this worker's infection status?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic infection with high infectivity

 

Option C:

 

The presence of HBsAg and HBeAg along with IgG anti-HBc suggests that the hospital worker has a chronic Hepatitis B infection with high levels of viral replication and infectivity.

 

 

Figure: Serological Markers of Hepatitis B virus in various stages of Hepatitis B infection

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute Hepatitis B patient with high infectivity - While the presence of HBeAg does indicate high infectivity, the presence of IgG anti-HBc without IgM anti-HBc would not typically indicate an acute infection.

 

Option B. Simple carrier with high infectivity - A simple carrier would not typically have HBeAg present.

 

Option D. Immunized person for Hepatitis B - Immunization leads to the presence of anti-HBs, not HBsAg or HBeAg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serological pattern in Hep B- 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p557, Ananthanaranyan 9/e p548

questions.text: In a patient with acute hepatitis B, which of the following serological markers is least likely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anti-HBsAb

 

Option D:

During the acute phase of hepatitis B infection, the patient's body has not yet produced significant levels of anti-HBs antibodies (anti-HBsAb). These antibodies typically appear after the clearance of HBsAg during the recovery phase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HBsAg - Elevated during the acute phase of infection.

 

Option B. IgM anti-HBc - Indicative of recent infection and therefore elevated in acute hepatitis B.

 

Option C. Total anti-HBc - Includes both IgM and IgG and is elevated during acute and chronic infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serological pattern in Hep B- 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p532, 2/e p557-558

choices.text: Chronic hepatitis in active stage
Chronic hepatitis with precore mutant
Recovery from previous infection of hepatitis B

questions.text: A patient's serological test shows negative HBsAg, undetectable HBV DNA, positive anti-HBc IgG antibody, and positive anti-HBs antibody. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recovery from previous infection of hepatitis B

 

 

Option D:

 

The presence of anti-HBs and anti-HBc IgG antibodies with a negative HBsAg and undetectable HBV DNA suggests past infection with subsequent clearance of the virus and development of immunity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute hepatitis window period - During the window period, anti-HBc IgM would be positive, and anti-HBs may not yet be present.

 

Option B. Chronic hepatitis in active stage - In active chronic hepatitis B, HBsAg and HBV DNA would typically be positive.

 

Option C. Chronic hepatitis with precore mutant - This would suggest a negative HBeAg with a positive HBsAg and detectable HBV DNA, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serological pattern in Hep B- 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p534, 2/e p557-558

choices.text: Coinfection with HBV and HEV

questions.text: A nurse presents with positive HBsAg and HBeAg serology. What does this indicate about the nurse's hepatitis B status?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute infectious hepatitis

 

Option A:

 

The presence of HBsAg and HBeAg is indicative of an active Hepatitis B infection. The term "acute infectious hepatitis" suggests that the nurse is in the acute phase of the infection and is highly infectious.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Coinfection with HBV and HEV - This cannot be determined without HEV-specific serology.

 

Option C. Acute noninfectious hepatitis - The presence of HBeAg indicates high levels of infectivity, which is contrary to this option.

 

Option D. Chronic hepatitis B infection - While chronic infection can also present with HBsAg and HBeAg, the term "acute" points towards a recent infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serological pattern in Hep B- 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p534-35, 2/e p557-558

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with chronic Hepatitis B infection presents with a flare of liver enzymes. Genetic testing of the virus reveals a precore mutant strain. Which of the following serological markers is characteristically absent in patients infected with precore mutant HBV?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. HBeAg

 

Option B:

 

Precore mutants of HBV are unable to produce HBeAg due to mutations in the precore region of the genome. Despite high levels of viral replication, HBeAg will be undetectable in these patients.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HBV DNA - Can be present and often high in precore mutant infections.

 

Option C. HBcAg - Is not typically measured in serum and is not affected by the precore mutation.

 

Option D. Anti-HBe - Also known as anti-HBe, typically present in patients with precore mutants as the immune system responds to the lack of HBeAg production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The precore mutants in Hepatitis B: Unable to form HBeAg

  • Escape mutants in Hepatitis B: Unable to form HBsAg.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastrys Essential of Medical Microbiology 1/e p534-35, 2/e p557-558, Ananthanarayan 9/e p546-8

questions.text: A healthcare worker receives a needlestick injury from a patient with Hepatitis B. The worker's Hepatitis B surface antibody (anti-HBs) titer is checked to determine immunity. Which anti-HBs titer indicates adequate protective immunity to Hepatitis B?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 10 IU/ml

 

Option D:

 

An anti-HBs titer of ≥10 IU/ml is considered protective against Hepatitis B virus infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 0.1 IU/ml - This level is not considered protective.

 

Option B. 1 IU/ml - This is below the protective threshold.

 

Option C. 5 IU/ml - This is below the commonly accepted protective level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To recognize an anti-HBs titer of ≥10 IU/ml as indicative of adequate immunity to Hepatitis B, which is critical for post-exposure prophylaxis and determining the need for revaccination.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p536, 2/e p558-559

questions.text: In a discussion about the genetic factors influencing the progression and clearance of hepatitis viruses, a specific association between a hepatitis virus and the HLA DR 5 genotype is mentioned. Which hepatitis virus is known to have an increased rate of clearance in individuals possessing the HLA DR 5 genotype?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis B

 

Option B:

 

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) has been found to have an increased rate of clearance in individuals who possess the HLA DR 5 genotype. The human leukocyte antigen (HLA) system plays a significant role in the immune response, and specific HLA genotypes can influence the course of viral infections. In the case of HBV, the presence of the HLA DR 5 genotype is associated with a more effective immune response leading to a higher likelihood of clearing the infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A Hepatitis A: Typically, self-limiting and does not usually require immune system genotyping for clearance.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C: Clearance is less associated with HLA DR 5 and more with HLA DRB1*11.

 

Option D. Hepatitis D: Requires HBV for its life cycle and is not directly cleared by HLA genotypes alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HLA DR 5 genotype has been associated with a better immune response and clearance of Hepatitis B virus. Individuals with this genotype are more likely to clear the virus and less likely to develop chronic Hepatitis B infection.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p538

choices.text: Genotype diagnosis is based on IgG HCV.
Pegylated interferon is the treatment of choice.
HCV real-time PCR is the molecular diagnostic method of choice.

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient presents for evaluation of Hepatitis C. Which of the following is a true statement regarding the diagnosis of Hepatitis C infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HCV real-time PCR is the molecular diagnostic method of choice.

 

Option D:

 

HCV RNA detection by real-time PCR is the molecular diagnostic method of choice for Hepatitis C, as it confirms active infection and can be used to monitor treatment response.

Direct-acting antiviral agents (DAAs) are the now the treatment of choice for HCV infection as they can produce sustainable viral response (SVR) rate up to 90% with minimal side effects.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Genotype diagnosis is based on IgG HCV - IgG HCV indicates exposure, not the genotype of HCV.

 

Option B. Spreads through feco-oral route - HCV is primarily spread through blood-to-blood contact, not the feco-oral route.

 

Option C. Pegylated interferon is the treatment of choice - This is outdated; direct-acting antivirals are now the standard of care.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The current diagnostic methods for Hepatitis C, particularly the role of HCV RNA PCR in confirming active infection and guiding treatment decisions.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p561

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, proteinuria, cryoglobulinemia, and glomerulonephritis. Which test is most appropriate to arrive at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-HCV antibody

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation is suggestive of HCV-associated mixed cryoglobulinemia. The anti-HCV antibody test is the appropriate initial diagnostic test for HCV infection. Due to deposition of circulating immune complexes (composed of HCV antigens and their antibodies) in extrahepatic sites, various manifestations can set in such as:

 

  •  Mixed cryoglobulinemia
  •  Glomerulonephritis
  •  Arthritis and joint pain.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ANCA - Associated with vasculitides such as Wegener's granulomatosis, not typically with HCV.

 

Option B. HBsAg - This would be appropriate if suspecting Hepatitis B, not indicated by the symptoms described.

 

Option D. MIF - Not relevant for this clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of cutaneous vasculitis, proteinuria, cryoglobulinemia, and glomerulonephritis suggests a systemic condition that could be associated with Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection. Testing for anti-HCV antibodies is the appropriate next step to confirm an HCV infection, which may be the underlying etiology of these symptoms.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med.Microbiology, 2/e, p560

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient with a history of intravenous drug use undergoes a liver biopsy after testing positive for Hepatitis C virus (HCV). Which histological feature is most characteristic of chronic HCV infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interface necrosis

 

Option C:

 

Interface necrosis, also known as piecemeal necrosis, is a characteristic histological feature of chronic hepatitis, including that caused by HCV infection. It refers to the necrosis of hepatocytes at the periphery of the lobules, where the liver tissue meets the fibrous tissue of the portal tracts.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ground glass appearance - This is typically associated with Hepatitis B infection due to the accumulation of viral surface antigens.

 

Option B. Bridging necrosis - While this can occur in chronic hepatitis, it is not as characteristic of HCV as interface necrosis.

 

Option D. Lymphoid aggregates - These can be found in chronic hepatitis but are not as diagnostic as interface necrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Histopathology of liver biopsy differentiating chronic hepatitis B and C infection:

  •  Chronic HCV quite commonly show Lymphoid aggregates or fully formed lymphoid follicle.
    • Bile duct injury is common with Hepatitis C infection mimicking primary biliary cirrhosis.
    • Hepatitis C genotype 3 infection shows fatty changes with scattered hepatocyte.
  •  Ground glass hepatocytes (cells with endoplasmic reticulum swollen by HBsAg) is hallmark for chronic Hepatitis B infection.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med Microbiology 1/e p537-38, 2/e p559-560, Robbins 9/e p837

questions.text: In a hospital safety training session, medical staff are being educated about the risks and implications of needlestick injuries. Part of the training focuses on the transmission probabilities of various hepatitis viruses through such injuries. Which hepatitis virus is associated with approximately a 3% chance of transmission following a needlestick injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatitis C

 

Option C:

 

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) has an estimated 3% chance of transmission through a needlestick injury, which is notably higher than the risk associated with HIV but lower than that for Hepatitis B virus, especially if the source patient is HBsAg and HBeAg positive.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A - This virus is primarily transmitted via the fecal-oral route, not through needlestick injuries.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B - The transmission risk is up to 30% for needlestick injuries if the source patient is highly infectious.

 

Option D. Hepatitis D - Also known as delta hepatitis, it requires the presence of Hepatitis B virus for its replication and transmission but has a lower transmission rate than HBV through needlestick injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) has an estimated transmission risk of approximately 3% following a needlestick injury. This rate is significant, though lower than that of Hepatitis B virus (HBV), especially in non-immunized individuals. Hepatitis A and D are not typically associated with high transmission risk through needlestick injuries.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p537, 2/e p559-560

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with chronic liver disease has a liver biopsy that shows cirrhotic changes. Serologic tests reveal the presence of a surface antigen associated with Hepatitis B infection. This antigen is commonly known as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

Option A:

 

HBsAg, or Hepatitis B surface antigen, is known as the Australian antigen and is the first serological marker that appears in the blood following infection with Hepatitis B virus. Its presence indicates ongoing HBV infection, which can be either acute or chronic.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HBeAg - This is a marker of active replication and infectivity but is not known as the Australian antigen.

 

Option C. HBcAg - This antigen is associated with the core of the HBV but is not the Australian antigen.

 

Option D. HBV DNA - While this indicates the presence of the virus in the liver, it is not the Australian antigen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBsAg is the surface antigen of Hepatitis B, also known as the Australian antigen, which is used as a marker for HBV infection in serologic testing.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p530, 2/e p552

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing data from a community screening program for Hepatitis B virus (HBV). Which of the following serological markers is most useful as an epidemiological marker to determine the rate of HBV infection in the community?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HBsAg

 

Option A:

 

Serological marker used to identify current infection with Hepatitis B virus and, when used in epidemiological studies, reflects the prevalence of the virus within a community.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HBeAg - Indicates active replication and high infectivity, but not used primarily for epidemiological screening.

 

Option C. Anti-HBe - Suggests lower levels of viral replication, but its absence does not rule out infection.

 

Option D. Anti-HBs - Indicates immunity to HBV from past infection or vaccination, not current infection rates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Epidemiological marker in HBV infection: HbsAg and Anti- HBc IgG for assessing the prevalence of HBV infection in a population during community health screenings.

 

Ref:   Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p534-35, 2/e p557-558, Park 24/e p230, 23/e p210-20

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient with chronic Hepatitis B is diagnosed with HIV. Which antiviral medication can be used to treat both conditions simultaneously?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Emtricitabine

 

Option D.

 

Emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) with activity against both HIV and Hepatitis B virus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Abacavir - It is an NRTI used for HIV but does not have activity against Hepatitis B.

 

Option B. Stavudine - Another NRTI for HIV without activity against Hepatitis B.

 

Option C. Enfuvirtide - A fusion inhibitor specific for HIV treatment and does not work against Hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emtricitabine as an antiviral medication effective against both HIV and Hepatitis B. Antiviral agents like Tenofovir and telbivudine are drug choice currently. Lamivudine, adefovir, Emtricitabine and entecavir can also be used

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology, 2/e p558

questions.text: A medical student is asked to describe the Hepatitis B vaccine during a presentation. Which of the following best describes the Hepatitis B vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Recombinant DNA vaccine

 

Option A:

 

The Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant DNA vaccine, which means it is produced by inserting the genetic material encoding the hepatitis B surface antigen into yeast cells, which then produce the antigen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Edible vaccine - Referenceers to a vaccine delivered through consumption of genetically modified food, not applicable to Hepatitis B.

 

Option C. Nuclear transformation - Not a term associated with vaccine production.

 

Option D. RNA vaccine - This describes a different type of vaccine technology not used for Hepatitis B.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B vaccine is a recombinant DNA vaccine, the first of its kind approved for human use.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p535-36, 2/e p558-559

choices.text: The patient had a past infection and is now a chronic carrier.
The patient has been vaccinated against Hepatitis B.
The patient is currently infectious and in the active phase of infection.
The patient has a concurrent Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection.

questions.text: A patient present with jaundice and fatigue. Blood tests return positive for both HBsAg and HBeAg. What is the most likely interpretation of these serological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The patient is currently infectious and in the active phase of infection.

 

Option C:

 

The presence of both HBsAg and HBeAg is indicative of active replication of the Hepatitis B virus and high infectivity. This serological profile suggests that the patient is in the acute, active phase of Hepatitis B infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The patient had a past infection and is now a chronic carrier - Chronic carriers may have HBsAg but are less likely to have HBeAg unless they are in the immune active phase.

 

Option B. The patient has been vaccinated against Hepatitis B - Vaccination leads to the presence of anti-HBs antibodies, not HBsAg or HBeAg.

 

Option D. The patient has a concurrent HEV infection - There is no direct link between these markers and HEV infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SEROLOGIC PATTERNS IN HEPATITIS B

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p534, 2/e p557

choices.text: Hepatitis E virus

questions.text: In a discussion about viral polymerases, a student asks which of the hepatitis viruses contains reverse transcriptase, an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase. Which virus should be identified?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hepatitis B virus

 

Option B:

 

Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is unique among hepatitis viruses in that it utilizes reverse transcriptase during its replication cycle, despite being a DNA virus. Reverse transcriptase is an RNA-dependent DNA polymerase.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A virus - This is an RNA virus that does not utilize reverse transcription.

 

Option C. Hepatitis E virus - Also an RNA virus, it replicates in the cytoplasm and does not use reverse transcriptase.

 

Option D. Hepatitis C virus - An RNA virus that replicates through RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The polymerase gene of Hepatitis B virus has three enzymatic activities: (i) DNA polymerase, (ii) Reverse transcriptase activity, (iii) RNAse. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p531, 2/e p553

questions.text: A virology professor is explaining the structure of Hepatitis B virus (HBV) to the class. The professor asks the students to identify the nature of HBV's genetic material. Which of the following is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Partially double-stranded DNA

 

Option D:

 

HBV has a partially double-stranded DNA genome. The DNA is not fully double-stranded; it has a complete negative-sense strand and an incomplete positive-sense strand.

 

 

Figure: Structure of Hepatitis B virus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Single-stranded DNA - This is incorrect as HBV's genome is not fully single-stranded.

 

Option B. Double-stranded DNA - This is incorrect as HBV's genome is not fully double-stranded.

 

Option C. Partially single-stranded DNA - This choice might cause confusion because while the HBV DNA does have single-stranded regions, it is more accurate to describe it as partially double-stranded due to the complete negative-sense strand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genetic structure of HBV is partially double-stranded DNA, which is unique among DNA viruses.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p530, 2/e p552, Ananthanarayan 9/e p543

questions.text: Which of the following hepatitis viruses is most associated with cryoglobulinemia, a condition characterized by the presence of abnormal proteins in the blood that precipitate at low temperatures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatitis C

 

Option C:

 

Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is most associated with cryoglobulinemia. This condition is an extrahepatic manifestation of chronic HCV infection. Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in cooler temperatures and dissolve upon rewarming. The presence of these abnormal proteins in patients with HCV can lead to a variety of symptoms, including vasculitis, renal disease, and skin manifestations.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A - Not typically associated with cryoglobulinemia.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B - While it can have extrahepatic manifestations, it is less commonly associated with cryoglobulinemia compared to HCV.

 

Option D. Hepatitis E - There is no significant association with cryoglobulinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis C virus infection is strongly associated with the development of cryoglobulinemia, which can lead to a variety of symptoms, including vasculitis and renal disease.

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p537, 2/e p560-561

choices.text: Most common indication for liver transplant
Does not cause liver cancer
Does not cause coinfection with hepatitis B

questions.text: Regarding Hepatitis C, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Most common indication for liver transplant

 

Option B:

 

Chronic Hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection is the most common indication for liver transplantation in many parts of the world. HCV can lead to chronic liver disease, including cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, which are primary reasons for liver transplantation. Advanced liver disease due to HCV is a significant health burden, and liver transplantation remains a vital treatment option for end-stage liver disease caused by this virus.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. DNA virus - This is incorrect; HCV is an RNA virus.

 

Option C. Does not cause liver cancer - This is incorrect; chronic HCV infection can lead to hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. Does not cause coinfection with hepatitis B - This is incorrect; coinfection with HBV and HCV can occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis C is the leading cause of liver transplants in the United States due to its tendency to cause chronic liver disease, cirrhosis, and eventually liver failure.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p536-38, 2/e p559-560, Harrison 20/e p2357

choices.text: Nonenveloped positive strand RNA virus

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with a history of blood transfusion 30 years ago presents with fatigue and abdominal discomfort. His liver function tests show elevated ALT and AST. Serological tests are positive for Hepatitis C antibodies, and HCV RNA quantitative PCR confirms active infection. Which of the following best describes the Hepatitis C virus (HCV)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enveloped RNA virus

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatitis C virus is an enveloped, positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus. The envelope is crucial for its entry into host cells. Belonging to family Flaviviridae.

 

Educational Objective:


Hepatitis C virus is an enveloped ssRNA virus.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p536-38, 2/e p559-560, Ananthanarayan 9/e p549

questions.text: A 37-year-old laboratory manager is reviewing the blood bank's screening protocols. According to the drug and cosmetic act, which of the following is not mandatory for screening of donated blood?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) West Nile virus

 

Option D:

 

Routine screening for West Nile virus in donated blood is not mandated by the drug and cosmetic act, although it may be screened in some regions during outbreaks.

According to the Drugs and Cosmetics Act, & Rule (1945), the blood banks who intend to supply blood units/components shall perform the following mandatory tests for screening of donated blood:

 

  • Blood grouping
  • Antibody testing
  • Hemoglobin content
  • Hepatitis B (HBsAg detection)
  • Hepatitis C (Anti HCV antibody detection)
  • Syphilis serology (VDRL)
  • HIV I and II antibody detection
  • Malaria parasite detection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. HIV - Mandatory to screen due to the risk of transmission and severe implications of infection.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B - Essential to screen due to its prevalence and risk of transmission.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C - Necessary to screen due to potential for chronic liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mandatory tests for screening of donated blood: Blood grouping, Antibody testing, Hemoglobin, Hepatitis B (HBsAg), Hepatitis C (Anti HCV antibody), Syphilis (VDRL), HIV I and II antibody and Malaria parasite detection.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p536-38, 2/e p559-560, Drugs and Cosmetics Act & Rule, 1945

choices.text: HDV causes more serious infection due to superinfection.
HDV cannot infect in the absence of HBV.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, known to have chronic Hepatitis B, presents with a sudden deterioration in her liver function tests. She denies any new medication or alcohol use. A new serological marker, delta antibody, is detected in her blood. Which statement about the co-infection of HBV and HDV is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HDV is a DNA virus.

 

Option D:

 

Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is an RNA virus, not a DNA virus. It requires Hepatitis B virus (HBV) for its replication.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Both can infect simultaneously - True, HDV can coinfect with HBV.

 

Option B. HDV causes more serious infection due to superinfection - True, HDV superinfection in chronic HBV patients can lead to more serious liver disease.

 

Option C. HDV cannot infect in the absence of HBV - True, HDV requires the presence of HBV to infect cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis D virus is an RNA virus that requires Hepatitis B virus for its life cycle, and superinfection with HDV can lead to more severe liver disease.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p538-39, 2/e p562-563, Ananthanarayan 9/e p549

questions.text: In a discussion about viral life cycles, a medical student asks about the nature of the Hepatitis D virus. Which of the following does the Hepatitis D virus require from its helper, the Hepatitis B virus, to propagate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) An envelope protein

 

Option A:

 

Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is a defective virus that requires the envelope proteins provided by Hepatitis B virus (HBV) to assemble and propagate.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Transcriptase to transcribe mRNA - HDV encodes its own transcriptase.

 

Option C. Replicase for its RNA - HDV can replicate its own RNA.

 

Option D. Reverse transcriptase - HDV does not use reverse transcriptase for replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dependent nature of HDV on HBV, specifically requiring the envelope proteins from HBV for its assembly and release from infected cells.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p538-39, 2/e p562-563, Ananthanarayan 9/e p549

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with acute viral hepatitis. She has recently traveled to a region with poor sanitation. Which viral hepatitis infection is associated with the highest maternal mortality during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis E

 

Option D:

 

Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection during pregnancy, especially in the third trimester, is associated with a high rate of maternal mortality, up to 20%.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatitis A - Generally not associated with increased maternal mortality.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B - May cause complications but not typically associated with high maternal mortality.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C - Generally does not increase maternal mortality during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risk of Hepatitis E virus infection during pregnancy, which can lead to fulminant hepatitis and a high maternal mortality rate.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p540, 2/e p563-564, Ananthanarayan 9/e p550

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with acute onset jaundice and clay-colored stools after returning from a trip to a developing country. He reports consuming local street food. A stool sample is positive for a non-enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus that is transmitted feco-orally. Which of the following is the most likely virus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatitis A

 

Option D:

 

Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is a non-enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus typically transmitted via the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated food or water.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hepatitis E - Although HEV is also transmitted feco-orally and could present similarly, HAV is more commonly associated with acute onset jaundice and clay-colored stools after travel.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B - HBV is a DNA virus, not RNA, and is not transmitted feco-orally.

 

Option C. Hepatitis C - HCV is not typically transmitted feco-orally.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A is a non-enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus that can cause acute hepatitis following ingestion of contaminated food or water, particularly in settings with poor sanitation.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p540, 2/e p563-564, Ananthanarayan 9/e p550
